entries.name: Bezoar
entries: A bezoar is a consumable magic item, similar to a potion, and you must swallow it whole to gain its effects. When you swallow it, you take {@damage 1d6 + 1} acid damage, and your hit point maximum is reduced by an equal amount for the bezoar's duration. The bezoar remains active in your belly for a number of days equal to the damage taken. After that time, you automatically regurgitate the used-up bezoar, for which you take another {@damage 1d6 + 1} acid damage, but your hit point maximum returns to normal. A used-up bezoar has no power and soon crumbles away.

A bezoar can be removed prior to its full duration with a {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check but still deals the secondary damage as you regurgitate it. A partially used bezoar recharges itself after being out of a body for 24 hours. Swallowing it again after that allows a new roll for duration. You can only have one bezoar active at a time, and while one is active, you do not gain any benefit from other consumable magic items, such as potions. While uncomfortable, this doesn't impact your ability to eat and drink though.

Owlbears are not picky eaters and wind up devouring all sorts of nastiness: carrion, furry creatures, fey river stones, feathery things, nut shells, fish bones, and shadow-fused bone. As such, any bezoar has a {@chance 50|50% chance|Bezoar|The bezoar is not cursed.|The bezoar is cursed.} of being cursed. You can't remove a cursed bezoar before its full duration (when you will regurgitate it as normal) unless you are first targeted by a {@spell remove curse} spell. However, if the bezoar is not removed before your next short or long rest after the spell's casting, the curse returns. The curse ends automatically once the bezoar is regurgitated.

altArt.name: Alseid Grovekeeper
altArt.tokenCredit: One of: Pedro Potier, Karl Waller, Maciej Zagorski

items.name: Blowgun
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 25/100 ft., one target. {@h}{@damage 1} piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage, or half poison damage with a successful {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw. If a creature takes 15 or more poison damage from a single blowgun attack, it is also {@condition paralyzed} until the end of its next turn (see {@item Sea Serpent Venom|KPSC} in the appendix).

items.name: Special Equipment
entries: Bastron is a standard quasit, but Maksilov provided it with a {@item Bastron's Potion|KPSC|unique potion} that combines the effects of {@item Potion of Heroism|DMG|heroism} and {@item Potion of Hill Giant Strength|DMG|hill giant strength}. Bastron keeps the small potion vial on a string around its neck. When it looks like a fight is about to break out (but ideally before initiative is rolled), Bastron drinks the potion. It doesn't need to hoard this potion because Maksilov can always make another, and she'd rather have Bastron use it to protect her than keep it corked.

altArt.name: Alseid Grovekeeper
altArt.tokenCredit: One of: Pedro Potier, Karl Waller, Maciej Zagorski

monster.name: Cagoth-ze

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Cagoth-ze is a 9th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). Cagoth-ze has the following wizard spells prepared:
footerEntries: * Spells with an asterisk are from the Kobold Press book Deep Magic.

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: Cagoth-ze also wears the {@item ring of being anchored in time|KPSC}, which renders him immune to the risks of the time tributary. This gives him an excellent ploy, if he can entice intruders to chase him through the raw time stream.

attachedItems: ring of being anchored in time|KPSC

items.name: Special Equipment
entries: Chansar the Pale wears a {@item ring of evasion}.

items.name: Turning Defiance
entries: Chansar and any wights within 30 feet of him have advantage on saving throws against effects that turn undead.

trait.name: Compact
entries: A clacker beetle soldier can occupy the same 5-foot space as one other clacker beetle soldier.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the beetle's space. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d8 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Clack
entries: The beetle clacks its mandibles to create a small but dangerous sonic boom. All creatures in a 15-foot cone take 6 ({@damage 1d10 + 1}) thunder damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw. When multiple beetles clack in the same turn and create overlapping cones, each affected creature makes just one Constitution saving throw with disadvantage and the result is applied against the total damage.

trait.name: Potion Drinker
entries: Maksilov can drink a potion as a bonus action. Besides the concoctions described below, she carries {@item potion of flying|DMG|potions of flying}, {@item potion of gaseous form|DMG|gaseous form}, and {@item potion of superior healing|DMG|superior healing}. If she faces more than four enemies, she also has a {@item potion of speed|DMG}.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage plus 11 ({@damage 2d10}) poison damage, and the creature is {@condition poisoned} until the start of Maksilov's next turn. A successful {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw halves the poison damage and prevents the {@condition poisoned} condition.

action.name: Take This, You Swine
entries: Maksilov sets off one of each concoction. The effect is centered on her space. All four effects are triggered even if she used up all of one or more concoctions previously.

action.name: Throw Concoction
entries: Maksilov throws one concoction as a grenade at a target within 20 feet. She has two of each concoction:

items.name: Bootblack Pudding:
entries: This concoction covers a 15-foot cube with sticky black pudding extract that lasts 1 minute. A creature that starts its turn in the area must make a successful {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or take 9 ({@damage 2d8}) acid damage and be {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}).

items.name: Gelatinous Cloud:
entries: This concoction creates a 15-foot cube of gelatinous vapor that lasts 1 minute. Every creature inside the cloud must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) acid damage, can't breathe, and is {@condition restrained}. A successful saving throw halves the damage and prevents restraint and suffocation. A creature that ends its turn inside the cloud takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) acid damage. A {@condition restrained} creature can escape by taking an action to make a {@dc 12} Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check, freeing itself and moving into an empty space of its choice within 5 feet of the cloud on a success.

items.name: Gray Melter:
entries: This concoction throws out vaporous fibers that cling to and dissolve metal. Nonmagical weapons and armor made of metal that are within 5 feet of the vial's target space are coated in the stuff. They immediately take a permanent, cumulative −1 penalty to attack rolls, damage rolls, and AC. Thereafter, roll any die for each affected weapon or armor at the start of Maksilov's turn; on an odd result, the item takes another −1 penalty. A weapon is destroyed when its penalty reaches −5. Armor is destroyed when its base AC is reduced to 10. The effect stops when the fibers are rinsed off with vinegar or wine (which can be found in Area 203).

items.name: Oozebomb:
entries: Every creature within 10 feet of the target space must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw. Those that fail take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) acid damage immediately and another 3 ({@damage 1d6}) acid damage at the start of their turn until the sticky acid is scraped off by using an action and making a successful {@dc 10} Dexterity check or until the acid is neutralized with vinegar or wine (available in Area 203).

trait.name: Dement Poison
entries: The derro dement smears its handaxe and its crossbow bolts with dement poison. A creature hit by the handaxe must make a successful {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition frightened}. While {@condition frightened} this way, the creature also has {@sense truesight} (60 feet). A {@condition frightened} creature repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself with a success.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The derro dement has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the derro dement has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The derro dement attacks once with its javelin and once with its handaxe.

action.name: Handaxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) slashing damage, and the creature is exposed to dement poison.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Light Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage, and the creature is exposed to dement poison.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The derro pariah's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 10}, {@hit 2} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The derro pariah has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the derro pariah has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Turquoise Essence
entries: The derro pariah coats its crossbow bolts and its dagger with the concentrated essence of the {@adventure turquoise stream|KPSC|7|404. Turquoise Spring} to cause cold damage (included in the attacks).

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage plus 11 ({@damage 2d10}) cold damage. A successful {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw halves the cold damage.

action.name: Light Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage plus 11 ({@damage 2d10}) cold damage. A successful {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw halves the cold damage.

reaction.name: Panic Shot
entries: When an enemy approaches within 5 feet of the derro pariah, the pariah can make one light crossbow attack against that enemy.

trait.name: Ooze Cube
entries: The cube takes up its entire space. Other creatures can enter the space, but a creature that does so is subjected to the cube's Engulf and has disadvantage on the saving throw. Creatures inside the cube can be seen but have total cover. A creature within 5 feet of the cube can take an action to pull a creature or object out of the cube. Doing so requires a successful {@dc 14} Strength check, and the creature making the attempt takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) acid damage.
The cube can hold only one Large creature or up to four Medium or smaller creatures inside it at a time.

trait.name: Transparent
entries: Even when the cube is in plain sight, it is {@condition invisible} to every creature that hasn't spotted it. A successful {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals the cube as a hazy outline to the creature that made the check. A creature that enters the cube's space while unaware of the cube is surprised by the cube and is subjected to its Engulf, as described under Ooze Cube.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}14 ({@damage 4d6}) acid damage.

action.name: Engulf
entries: The cube moves up to its speed. While doing so, it can enter Large or smaller creatures' spaces. Whenever the cube enters a creature's space, the creature must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw. On a successful save, the creature can choose to be pushed 5 feet back or to the side of the cube. A creature that chooses not to be pushed suffers the consequences of a failed saving throw. On a failed save, the cube enters the creature's space and the creature takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) acid damage and is engulfed. The engulfed creature can't breathe, is {@condition restrained}, and takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the cube's turns. When the cube moves, the engulfed creature moves with it.
An engulfed creature can try to escape by taking an action to make a {@dc 14} Strength check. On a success, the creature escapes and enters a space of its choice within 5 feet of the cube.

action.name: Slimy Thoughts
entries: The ooze establishes telepathic contact with one creature within 30 feet of the ooze, but its thought processes are so alien they register on humanoid minds as a psychic assault. The target creature takes 22 ({@damage 5d8}) psychic damage or half damage with a successful {@dc 9} Intelligence saving throw.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The dire owlbear has advantage on melee attack rolls against a creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The dire owlbear has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dire owlbear makes one attack with its beak and one attack with its claws.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) slashing damage.

items.name: Breath Weapon (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: Drakustanz exhales a 15-foot cone of flame. Every creature in the cone takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage or half damage with a successful {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw.

items: telepathy 240 ft.

items.name: Chuul Lightning Gun
entries: The gun can shoot a {@spell lightning bolt} every other round (100-foot line; {@damage 8d6} lightning damage; save {@dc 13}; can be fired only by someone with chuul claws and telepathy).

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The hybrid can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Death Burst
entries: When the hybrid dies, it liquifies into a thick, sticky puddle. Every creature in the hybrid's space or within 10 feet of it must make a successful {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw or take 4 ({@damage 1d8}) acid damage and have its speed reduced to 0 until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Mire
entries: A creature that starts its turn in the hybrid's space takes 4 ({@damage 1d8}) acid damage and its speed is reduced to 0 until the start of its next turn. A successful {@dc 12} Strength saving throw halves the damage and prevents the speed reduction.

A {@condition prone} creature has disadvantage on the saving throw and the damage is doubled to 18 ({@dice 4d8}). The first time a creature enters the hybrid's space during a turn, the creature must make a successful {@dc 12} Strength saving throw or its speed is reduced to 0 until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Ooze Blob
entries: Other creatures can enter the hybrid's space, but the first time a creature does so during a turn, it's affected by the hybrid's Mire. A creature within 5 feet of the hybrid can take an action to pull a creature or object out of the hybrid. Doing so requires a successful {@dc 12} Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check, and the creature making the attempt takes 9 ({@damage 2d8}) acid damage.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The hybrid can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hybrid makes two pseudopod attacks.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) acid damage, and the creature must make a successful {@dc 12} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Ooze Eruption {@recharge}
entries: A gas bubble forms inside the hybrid and bursts, splashing ooze all around. Every creature in the hybrid's space or within 15 feet of it takes 18 ({@damage 4d8}) acid damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw. Creatures that fail the saving throw are also knocked {@condition prone}.

reaction.name: Split and Rejoin
entries: When a hybrid is subjected to lightning or slashing damage, its Multiattack increases by one pseudopod attack (from two to three, from three to four, etc.), and Ooze Eruption recharges automatically.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Gellert the Gruesome is a 16th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 18}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks). Gellert has the following sorcerer spells prepared.
footerEntries: * Spells marked with an asterisk are from Deep Magic; their descriptions are in the appendix.

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: In addition to his listed traits, Gellert wears a {@item brooch of shielding} that gives him resistance to force damage and immunity to {@spell magic missile}, and a {@item cloak of protection} that grants him +1 to his AC and saving throws. These bonuses aren't included in his stats. {@note Plutonium will apply these on import to Foundry.}

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Gellert the Gruesome has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Dragon Wings
entries: As a bonus action, Gellert sprouts black dragon wings and gains a flying speed of 30 feet. The wings remain until he dismisses them as a bonus action.

trait.name: Empowered Spells
entries: When Gellert rolls damage dice for a spell, he can reroll up to five of the dice. He must use the new rolls.

trait.name: Heightened Spells
entries: When Gellert casts a spell that causes a creature to make a saving throw, Gellert can force one target of the spell to make its first saving throw with disadvantage.

trait.name: Ley Line Acclimatization
entries: Gellert's spellcasting and other magic use doesn't trigger {@table Chaos Magic Surge|DM07|chaos magic}.

trait.name: Quickened Spells
entries: Spells that have a casting time of 1 action can be cast as bonus actions by Gellert the Gruesome. He is still limited to casting one spell per turn.

action.name: Unquiet Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) psychic damage, and the creature must make a successful {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw or become {@condition frightened}. A {@condition frightened} creature repeats the saving throw at the end of its turn, ending the effect on itself with a success.

legendary.name: Cantrip
entries: Gellert casts a cantrip.

legendary.name: Unquiet Dagger
entries: Gellert makes one attack with the {@item unquiet dagger|KPSC}.

legendary.name: Misty Step (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Gellert casts {@spell misty step}.

altArt.name: Gellert the Gruesome
altArt.tokenCredit: One of: Pedro Potier, Karl Waller, Maciej Zagorski

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Imortra is an 11th-level spellcaster. Her spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). She has the following spells prepared.
footerEntries: * Spells marked with an asterisk are fiendish magic from Deep Magic. Full descriptions are included in the section Deep Magic Spells in the appendix.

trait.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: Imortra has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and magic can't put her to sleep.

trait.name: Focused Conjuration
entries: Imortra's {@status concentration} on a conjuration spell can't be broken as a result of taking damage.

trait.name: Purple Worm Poison
entries: The first creature hit by Imortra's shortsword takes an additional 42 ({@damage 12d6}) poison damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw. She can renew the poison once by spending an action doing so.

action.name: Benign Transposition (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: Imortra teleports to an unoccupied space within 30 feet that she can see. Alternatively, she can choose a space within 30 feet that is occupied by a Small or Medium ally; both creatures teleport, swapping places.

action.name: Refresh Poison (1/Day)
entries: Imortra re-coats her shortsword with {@item purple worm poison}. The next creature hit by the dagger is affected by the poison (see her Purple Worm Poison trait).

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage. The first creature hit by the dagger also takes additional poison damage (see her Purple Worm Poison trait).

altArt.name: Alseid Grovekeeper
altArt.tokenCredit: One of: Pedro Potier, Karl Waller, Maciej Zagorski

trait.name: Asp Venom
entries: Keluikinj poisons his weapons with a toxin distilled from asp venom. Creatures struck by his weapon attacks take 9 ({@dice 2d8}) additional poison damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw against poison (included in the attacks).

trait.name: Twisted
entries: When the dust goblin attacks a creature from hiding, its target must make a successful {@dc 10} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Wasteland Frenzy (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: For 1 minute, Keluikinj and dust goblins allied to him can add {@dice 1d4} to their attack rolls and saving throws, provided they can see and hear Keluikinj.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Keluikinj attacks twice with his shortsword.

action.name: Light Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage or half poison damage with a successful {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage or half the poison damage with a successful {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (1/Day)
headerEntries: The mephit can innately cast {@spell sleep} or {@spell acid splash} ({@damage 2d6} damage), requiring no material components. Its innate spellcasting ability is Charisma.

trait.name: Death Burst
entries: When the mephit dies, it explodes in a burst of dust. Each creature within 5 feet of it must then succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} for 1 minute and take 3 ({@damage 1d6}) acid damage. A {@condition blinded} creature can repeat the saving throw on each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) slashing damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) acid damage.

action.name: Blinding Breath {@recharge}
entries: The mephit exhales a 15-foot cone of blinding dust. Each creature in that area takes 5 ({@damage 2d4}) acid damage and must succeed on a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition blinded} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (1/Day)
headerEntries: The mephit can innately cast {@spell fog cloud} or {@spell acid splash} ({@damage 2d6} damage), requiring no material components. Its innate spellcasting ability is Charisma.

trait.name: Death Burst
entries: When the mephit dies, it explodes in a burst of jagged ice. Each creature within 5 feet of it must make a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw, taking 4 ({@damage 1d8}) slashing damage and 3 ({@damage 1d6}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much slashing damage on a successful one.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the mephit remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary shard of ice.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) slashing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) cold damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) acid damage.

action.name: Frost Breath {@recharge}
entries: The mephit exhales a 15-foot cone of cold air. Each creature in that area takes 5 ({@damage 2d4}) acid damage and must succeed on a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw, taking 5 ({@damage 2d4}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (1/Day)
headerEntries: The mephit can innately cast {@spell heat metal} (spell save {@dc 10}) or {@spell acid splash} ({@damage 2d6} damage), requiring no material components. Its innate spellcasting ability is Charisma.

trait.name: Death Burst
entries: When the mephit dies, it explodes in a burst of lava. Each creature within 5 feet of it must make a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw, taking 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage and 3 ({@damage 1d6}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much fire damage on a successful one.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the mephit remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary mound of magma.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) slashing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) fire damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) acid damage.

action.name: Fire Breath {@recharge}
entries: The mephit exhales a 15-foot cone of fire. Each creature in that area takes 5 ({@damage 2d4}) acid damage and must make a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw, taking 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (1/Day)
headerEntries: The mephit can innately cast {@spell blur} or {@spell acid splash} ({@damage 2d6} damage), requiring no material components. Its innate spellcasting ability is Charisma.

trait.name: Death Burst
entries: When the mephit dies, it explodes in a cloud of steam. Each creature within 5 feet of the mephit takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) acid damage and must succeed on a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw or take 4 ({@damage 1d8}) fire damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) slashing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) fire damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) acid damage.

action.name: Steam Breath {@recharge}
entries: The mephit exhales a 15-foot cone of scalding steam. Each creature in that area takes 5 ({@damage 2d4}) acid damage and must succeed on a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw, taking 4 ({@damage 1d8}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

items.name: Battleaxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) slashing damage, or 7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) slashing damage if used with two hands.

items.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The phantom wight can move through other creatures and objects as if they were {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

items.name: Bonded Ring-Staff (7/Day)
entries: When the ring warden wight rolls damage for a spell attack while holding its ring-staff, it adds +3 to the result. The ring warden wight can use the ring-staff as an {@item arcane focus|PHB}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The ring warden wight is a 7th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks).
footerEntries: * Spells marked with an asterisk are from Deep Magic by Kobold Press. These spells are also included elsewhere in the appendix under Deep Magic Spells.

trait.name: Camouflage
entries: The saber-toothed bat has advantage on {@skill Stealth} checks in caves.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The saber-toothed bat doesn't provoke an {@action opportunity attack} when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
entries: The saber-toothed bat has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing, and it can't be surprised while in a cave.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the saber-toothed bat flies at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with its claw attack on the same turn, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the bat can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) piercing damage. If the creature is {@condition prone}, it takes an additional 3 ({@damage 1d6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) slashing damage.

items.name: Berserker's Blood {@recharge 5}
entries: If Scar doesn't have all of his hp, he flexes and roars, spraying blood from his wounds. Each creature within 15 feet of Scar must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) acid damage and goes berserk. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and doesn't go berserk. On each of its turns, a berserk creature must attack the nearest creature it can see, eschewing ranged or magical attacks in favor of melee attacks. If no creature is near enough to move to and attack, the berserk creature attacks an object, with preference for an object smaller than itself. Once a creature goes berserk it repeats the saving throw at the end of its turn, ending the effect on itself on a success, otherwise it continues to do so until it is {@condition unconscious}, regains all of its hp, or is cured through {@spell lesser restoration} or similar magic.

items.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: Scar has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hp.

items.name: Multiattack
entries: Scar attacks once with his greatclub and once with a javelin.

items.name: Rejuvenation
entries: Solnis regains all her hit points if the body is submerged in the Black River for 1 hour. She doesn't rejuvenate if the body is placed on dry land, if {@spell gentle repose} or comparable magic is cast on the body, or if a {@spell hallow} spell is cast on the portion of the Black River where she drowned.

items.name: Hair
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d10 + 3}) slashing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). Three creatures can be {@condition grappled} at a time. Solnis can use Reel as a bonus action on a hit.

trait.name: Constant Clacking
entries: A creature that starts its turn in the swarm's space takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) thunder damage.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny creature. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the swarm's space. {@h}14 ({@damage 4d6}) piercing damage, or 7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer.

altArt.name: Alseid Grovekeeper
altArt.tokenCredit: One of: Pedro Potier, Karl Waller, Maciej Zagorski

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The chained thing has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The chained thing regains 20 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point. If the chained thing takes radiant damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The chained thing makes one slam attack and uses Infectious Insanity.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Infectious Insanity
entries: The chained thing chooses a creature it can see within 30 feet and magically assaults its mind. The creature must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or be affected as if by a {@spell confusion} spell for 1 minute. An affected creature repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Necrotic Wave {@recharge 5}
entries: The chained thing shudders and emits a pulse of necrotic energy. All creatures within 20 feet take 27 ({@damage 6d8}) necrotic damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. Creatures that fail the saving throw are also knocked {@condition prone} and {@condition incapacitated} until the end of their next turn.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The Gaoler has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Horrific Appearance
entries: Any humanoid that starts its turn within 30 feet of the Gaoler and can see him must make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, with disadvantage if the Gaoler is within line of sight, ending the effect on itself on a success.
If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the Gaoler's Horrific Appearance for the next 24 hours.

Unless the target is surprised, the target can avert its eyes and avoid making the initial saving throw. Until the start of its next turn, a creature that averts its eyes has disadvantage on attack rolls against the Gaoler.

action.name: Maul
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Psychic Horrors
entries: The Gaoler targets one {@condition frightened} creature he can see within 30 feet. The target must make a successful {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or drop to 0 hit points.

trait.name: Evasion
entries: If the ghostly foe is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, the ghostly foe instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw and only half damage if it fails.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The ghostly foe can move through other creatures and objects as if they were {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The ghostly foe has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Possession
entries: A humanoid that the ghostly foe has damaged must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or be possessed by the ghostly foe. The DC for the saving throw equals the psychic damage done by the attack. If the saving throw fails, the ghostly foe disappears and the target loses control of its body. The ghostly foe now controls the body but doesn't deprive the target of awareness. The ghostly foe can't be targeted by any attack, spell, or other effect, and it retains its alignment, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma, and Magic Resistance. It otherwise uses the possessed target's statistics, and it does have access to the target's knowledge, class features, and proficiencies.

At the end of the possessed creature's turn, it must make a successful {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw or become {@condition petrified}. The possessed creature can choose to fail this saving throw automatically.

The possession lasts until the body drops to 0 hit points, the ghostly foe ends it as a bonus action, the body is {@condition petrified}, or the ghostly foe is forced out by {@spell dispel evil and good} or comparable magic. When the possession ends, this manifestation of the ghostly foe dissipates.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one creature. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) psychic damage, and the creature must make a saving throw against the ghostly foe's Possession.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) slashing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) psychic damage, and the creature must make a saving throw against the ghostly foe's Possession.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Ushulx is a 4th-level spellcaster. Her spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 11}, {@hit 3} to hit with spell attacks). Ushulx has the following cleric spells prepared:
footerEntries: * Spells marked with an asterisk are from the Kobold Press book Deep Magic. They're repeated in the Deep Magic Spells section for convenience.

monster.name: Warlock Wight

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with silvered weapons

resist.special: plus one other damage type of its choosing (see fiend's luck)

languages: the languages it knew in life

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The warlock wight's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). The wight can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components.

trait.name: Fiend's Luck
entries: At the start of an encounter, the warlock wight chooses one of the following damage types to have resistance to: acid, cold, fire, force, lightning, psychic, radiant, or thunder.

trait.name: Headless Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the warlock wight to 0 hit points, it collapses as if destroyed. At the start of its next turn, it regains 25 hit points, provided the damage that destroyed it wasn't from a critical hit. Only the wight's head becomes active; the body remains inert. The wight retains all its stats and abilities except its Claws attack, which it can't use. It doesn't regain the use of expended spells.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the warlock wight has disadvantage on attack rolls and on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Life Drain
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) necrotic damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or its hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

A humanoid slain by this attack rises 24 hours later as a {@creature zombie|MM} under the warlock wight's control, unless the humanoid is restored to life or its body is destroyed. The wight can have no more than twelve {@creature zombie|MM|zombies} under its control at one time.

items.name: Spider Climb
entries: Xymargshra can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Xymargshra's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
footerEntries: * Spells marked with an asterisk are Void magic spells from Deep Magic. Their full descriptions are included under Deep Magic Spells in the appendix.

altArt.name: Zula the Witch
altArt.tokenCredit: One of: Pedro Potier, Karl Waller, Maciej Zagorski

images.title: Barrett, The Red Hart
images.credit: One of: Miguel Regodn Harkness, Marcel Mercado, William O'Brien, Sam Perin, Florian Stitz, Bryan Syme, Egil Thompson, Jon Pintar

monsterFluff.name: Cagoth-ze
entries: The lower ranking of {@creature Gellert the Gruesome|KPSC|Gellert the Gruesome's} two lieutenants is the gnome wizard Cagoth-ze. He left his ancestral home in Neimheim decades ago after a long-running squabble with his brother turned deadly over a birthright. Fratricide isn't that shocking in the Nine Cities, but Cagoth-ze was the unpopular one of the two siblings. His brother's allies would have killed him (or worse), so he departed for safer territory. In light of his fascination with ley lines, conjurations, and time manipulation, he couldn't have landed in a better spot than the ancient scriptorium of the elves beneath the Scarlet Citadel. The gnome bemusedly considers murdering his brother to be the best thing he ever did.

Cagoth-ze uses the standard stat block for an NPC {@creature mage} but with an altered spell list. Spells with an asterisk are from the Kobold Press book Deep Magic. Their descriptions are included in the section Deep Magic Spells for reference.

The gnome carries a small ring of keys to unlock the doors in Areas 210, 215, and 217. He also wears a simple gold stickpin in his waistcoat that allows him to open and close those doors as if they're unlocked without using the keys. This item can be a lifesaver if he finds himself running from an enemy through hallways and chambers. It works only on those three locks.

Cagoth-ze also wears the {@item ring of being anchored in time|KPSC}, which renders him immune to the risks of the time tributary. This gives him an excellent ploy, if he can entice intruders to chase him through the raw time stream.

monsterFluff.name: Clacker Beetles
entries: Clacker beetles are aggressive subterranean scavengers. Individually they aren't much of a threat, but they're never encountered individually. Worker clacker beetles and immature beetles form swarms, and soldiers always scavenge in groups.

The beetles get their name from the deadly clacking sound produced by their mandibles. They can hook their mandibles together and apply tremendous force to the pair, then snap them apart at greater than the speed of sound. The sonic boom this generates hits with the force of a sledgehammer. Clacker beetles use this attack to stun or kill potential prey. When they're encountered in large groups, the rapid-fire clacking of their mandibles can quickly bring down creatures as large as trolls and ogres.
Clacker beetles nest by chewing holes into rock and rubble. A small cavern riddled with clacker beetle tunnels can house hundreds or thousands of the creatures.

They're fond of shiny objects, much as crows and pack rats are. When clacker beetles infest ancient tombs or other sites where valuables are stored, they've been known to snatch nearly all the gold, silver, and jewels and drag it to their nesting site.

monsterFluff.name: Danaska Maksilov
entries: The resident alchemist who's experimenting with the alchemist's furnace is Danaska Maksilov. She was chased away from her home city of Khorsburg by a murderous mob after an experiment gone awry released clouds of maddening vapor that rolled through the neighborhood and transformed livestock and household pets into murderous oozes. As Maksilov fled westward, she heard rumors of the Scarlet Citadel and the legendary alchemical engine buried beneath it. She found the furnace idle and ignored, and she persuaded {@creature Cagoth-ze|KPSC} to let her study it in exchange for potions that could calm the voices in his head.

Maksilov has since devoted herself to figuring out the furnace's workings and putting it to use. Guided by a few hints in scroll fragments found in the scriptorium, her progress has been painfully slow. Mostly she learns from trial and error.

Though Maksilov is a near-genius alchemist, she is also unimaginative, mentally unstable, and obsessed with oozes. Those three traits have severely hampered her progress. Mishaps in some of her early experiments (that she misinterpreted as unforeseen successes) produced ooze-like substances. She became convinced ooze was the key to reconstructing {@i prima materia} (the primordial building block of {@i everything}), and all her research has gone down that path ever since.

Maksilov's greatest fear is that other mages and alchemists will steal her ideas before she can see them through to fruition. {@creature Cagoth-ze|KPSC} and {@creature Bastronombecqua|KPSC|Bastron} are the only creatures she trusts. She might be willing to talk to martial-type characters and even to clerics and druids (with reservations), but her paranoia over intellectual theft eventually derails any conversation with a practitioner of the arcane. Even then, she has little patience for talk about anything other than alchemy and oozes.

Her companion {@creature Bastronombecqua|KPSC} ("Bastron") is a {@creature quasit}. It was generated spontaneously inside the furnace during a transmutation that was a failure in all other respects. {@creature Bastronombecqua|KPSC|Bastron} is technically a demon but it has never been to the Abyss or spent any time around other demons. It knows nothing about anything except the alchemist's furnace and the first, second, and third layers of the Scarlet Citadel. It is entirely loyal to {@creature Danaska Maksilov|KPSC|Maksilov}, its creator.

monsterFluff.name: Derro
entries: All derro are corrupted and borderline insane, but the derro living in the bowels of the Scarlet Citadel are worse than most. They were driven out of their clan 150 years ago for carrying their worship of {@creature Camazotz, Demon Lord of Bats and Fire|ToB|Camazotz, demon lord of bats}, to extremes not even their fellow derro could tolerate. The cult's high priest {@creature Gilsfeyr|KPSC} led them along the Black River until they discovered a cavern filled with monstrous bats, where they settled and carved out a temple to their foul deity.

Since then, they've split into two camps. {@creature Gilsfeyr|KPSC}'s fanatics are the {@creature Derro Pariah|KPSC|pariahs}. The {@creature Derro Dement|KPSC|dements} are followers of {@creature Kurgorom|KPSC}, a witch queen whose experiments with fungal extracts produced a mild poison that allows the derro to see and coexist in parallel realities.

monsterFluff.name: Dire Gelatinous Cube
entries: One of {@creature Danaska Maksilov|KPSC|Danaska Maksilov's} crowning achievements is the creation of a gelatinous cube with superior speed, strength, and intellect—and limited psychic ability.

monsterFluff.name: Dire Owlbear
entries: The dwarves of the Scarlet Citadel selectively bred owlbears for toughness, ferocity, and slightly more discipline and intelligence. They also managed to introduce a bulette trait they considered desirable into the creatures: specifically, the ability to burrow rapidly. The dwarves termed the result "dire owlbears," although that label isn't really correct. Most "dire" creatures are primitive branches of a family tree that managed to survive for eons unchanged from more savage versions, usually in isolated regions far from civilization.

Because of the armor plating they wear, dire owlbears are sometimes misidentified as mutated or freakish bulettes by {@condition frightened} travelers and farmers whose horses and other livestock these monstrosities prey on.

images.title: Dire Owlbear
images.credit: One of: Miguel Regodn Harkness, Marcel Mercado, William O'Brien, Sam Perin, Florian Stitz, Bryan Syme, Egil Thompson, Jon Pintar

monsterFluff.name: Drakustanz
entries: Drakustanz is a captive of {@creature Gilsfeyr|KPSC} whose mind has been turned to unresisting mush by a diet of ego-crushing lichen extract. The dragonborn now does whatever {@creature Gilsfeyr|KPSC} commands, as if he's under the effect of a {@spell dominate person} spell. Unlike the victim of a magic spell, Drakustanz gets no saving throw against this effect no matter what {@creature Gilsfeyr|KPSC} orders him to do. And even when {@creature Gilsfeyr|KPSC} doesn't issue a command, Drakustanz does his best to protect his master and align his every action with what {@creature Gilsfeyr|KPSC} might want.
Drakustanz uses the standard {@creature gladiator} stat block with two additions. Being a red dragonborn, he is resistant to fire damage and has a breath weapon.

images.credit: One of: Miguel Regodn Harkness, Marcel Mercado, William O'Brien, Sam Perin, Florian Stitz, Bryan Syme, Egil Thompson, Jon Pintar

monsterFluff.name: Gelatinous Cube/Ochre Jelly Hybrid
entries: {@creature Danaska Maksilov|KPSC} tried for years to create this monstrous hybrid. She has no purpose in mind for it; to her, it's a fascinating challenge for her alchemical ability. Thankfully, the necessary equipment exists in only one place and the necessary knowledge resides only in Maksilov's obsessive mind and notes. If those things are destroyed, no more of these creatures should ever be created.

monsterFluff.name: Gellert the Gruesome
entries: As the only living scion of the Holzanger family, Gellert has authority over the land around the Scarlet Citadel and responsibilities toward its inhabitants. He ignores all of that unfortunately, and always has, in favor of pursuing knowledge and power at what he considers the most consequential magical site in all of Midgard, and coincidentally his own ancestral basement: the deep dungeon beneath the citadel.

Gellert isn't insane or obsessed, but he is deeply antisocial and misanthropic. He has no interest in or use for other people beyond whatever service they can render him. He meets with {@creature Imortra the Debased|KPSC} occasionally and shares glimpses of his research with her because he needs someone to keep an eye on matters elsewhere in the catacombs. His interest in her begins and ends with his own security.
He has even less interest in other people. Crusading adventurers present an interesting puzzle: how can their deaths contribute to Gellert's store of knowledge?

His appellation "the Gruesome" was applied by locals as something of a joke. Since no one ever saw him, stories sprang up that he was horribly disfigured. His scars were blamed on a magical experiment gone wrong or on being dunked in the Black River by his father moments after his birth. In fact, Gellert might have been handsome in his youth. Decades of living underground in the intense magical fluctuations of nearby ley lines have left him with pasty, flaccid flesh, glazed eyes, and skin lesions that never heal. He now deserves to be called gruesome, but the irony is that no one aside from {@creature Imortra the Debased|KPSC|Imortra} has ever seen him this way.
Although Void magic spells are generally restricted to wizards, Gellert's close ties to the Void give him access to knowledge that's denied to other sorcerers.

In addition to his listed traits, Gellert wears a {@item brooch of shielding} that gives him resistance to force damage and immunity to {@spell magic missile}, and a {@item cloak of protection} that grants him +1 to his AC and saving throws. These bonuses aren't included in his stats.

images.title: Concept Art from {@loader Warlock 20: Redtower|adventure/Kobold Press; Warlock 20 Redtower.json}
images.credit: One of: Pedro Potier, Karl Waller, Maciej Zagorski

entries: All derro are corrupted and borderline insane, but the derro living in the bowels of the Scarlet Citadel are worse than most. They were driven out of their clan 150 years ago for carrying their worship of {@creature Camazotz, Demon Lord of Bats and Fire|ToB|Camazotz, demon lord of bats}, to extremes not even their fellow derro could tolerate. The cult's high priest {@creature Gilsfeyr|KPSC} led them along the Black River until they discovered a cavern filled with monstrous bats, where they settled and carved out a temple to their foul deity.

Since then, they've split into two camps. {@creature Gilsfeyr|KPSC}'s fanatics are the {@creature Derro Pariah|KPSC|pariahs}. The {@creature Derro Dement|KPSC|dements} are followers of {@creature Kurgorom|KPSC}, a witch queen whose experiments with fungal extracts produced a mild poison that allows the derro to see and coexist in parallel realities.

images.credit: One of: Miguel Regodn Harkness, Marcel Mercado, William O'Brien, Sam Perin, Florian Stitz, Bryan Syme, Egil Thompson, Jon Pintar

monsterFluff.name: Imortra the Debased
entries: {@creature Imortra the Debased|KPSC} is an elf wizard who's fanatically devoted to {@creature Gellert the Gruesome|KPSC}. She heard tales about the unique magical properties of the Scarlet Citadel region from elves who saw those properties firsthand centuries ago, before the Holzanger family laid any claim over the area. Those tales drew Imortra to the citadel to study, and {@creature Gellert the Gruesome|KPSC|Gellert} was already there. Their peculiar interests overlapped, and because {@creature Gellert the Gruesome|KPSC|Gellert} was far ahead of Imortra in knowledge and understanding, he became the master and she the student. But they are also collaborators.

Imortra's name originated during the years of her early adulthood, when her research and experiments in conjuring elementals and devils resulted in repeated tragedies. Traditional elements of her elven community considered such things to be "dark arts," and they condemned her for tapping into evils she didn't understand and couldn't control. When her conjurations resulted in innocent deaths, Imortra was banned from the elven community for two centuries.
Spells in Imortra's spell list marked with an asterisk (*) are fiendish magic from Deep Magic. Full descriptions are included in the section Deep Magic Spells in the appendix.

monsterFluff.name: Keluikinj, Dust Goblin Firstblade
entries: The leader (firstblade) of the dust goblin raiding party is a veteran of many such incursions named Keluikinj. Like most dust goblins who rise to positions of leadership in their tribe, Keluikinj's mind is twisted and grim. He's no more sadistic than most dust goblins, but he has a fascination with the Void—or at least with the idea of the Void, as his understanding of the Void's nature is only a caricature of reality. Based on what he's seen inside the citadel, Keluikinj believes {@creature Cagoth-ze|KPSC} and {@creature Danaska Maksilov|KPSC} have a connection to the Void that he'd like to exploit. They don't, but that belief is what's stopped the dust goblins so far from finishing what they came here for, which is murder and looting. The other dust goblins in Keluikinj's group are losing patience with his delays and are on the verge of killing him so they can get on with killing everyone else.

images.title: Battlemage Konrad of Runkelstad
images.credit: One of: Miguel Regodn Harkness, Marcel Mercado, William O'Brien, Sam Perin, Florian Stitz, Bryan Syme, Egil Thompson, Jon Pintar

They were driven out of their clan 150 years ago for carrying their worship of {@creature Camazotz, Demon Lord of Bats and Fire|ToB|Camazotz, demon lord of bats}, to extremes not even their fellow derro could tolerate. The cult's high priest {@creature Gilsfeyr|KPSC} led them along the Black River until they discovered a cavern filled with monstrous bats, where they settled and carved out a temple to their foul deity.

Since then, they've split into two camps. {@creature Gilsfeyr|KPSC}'s fanatics are the {@creature Derro Pariah|KPSC|pariahs}. The {@creature Derro Dement|KPSC|dements} are followers of {@creature Kurgorom|KPSC}, a witch queen whose experiments with fungal extracts produced a mild poison that allows the derro to see and coexist in parallel realities.

items.credit: One of: Miguel Regodn Harkness, Marcel Mercado, William O'Brien, Sam Perin, Florian Stitz, Bryan Syme, Egil Thompson, Jon Pintar

images.credit: One of: Miguel Regodn Harkness, Marcel Mercado, William O'Brien, Sam Perin, Florian Stitz, Bryan Syme, Egil Thompson, Jon Pintar

monsterFluff.name: Ooze Mephit
entries: There's actually no such thing as a true ooze mephit, because ooze is not an elemental combination. The creatures that skulk around the alchemist's furnace are dust, ice, magma, and steam mephits that were altered by absorbing ooze plasma. Each type uses its standard stat block but with the following alterations and additions. These modifications don't change the mephit's challenge rating.

entries.name: Damage Immunities
entries: Add acid.

entries.name: Death Burst
entries: A creature that fails its saving throw also takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) acid damage in addition to the standard effects.

entries.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: The mephit can choose between its listed spell or {@spell acid splash} (7 [{@damage 2d6}] damage).

entries.name: Claws
entries: A hit deals 2 ({@damage 1d4}) acid damage in addition to other listed damage.

entries.name: Breath Weapon
entries: The attack deals 5 ({@damage 2d4}) acid damage in addition to other listed damage and effects.

monsterFluff.name: Phantom Wight
entries: A phantom wight uses the stat block of a normal {@creature wight} but with the addition of Incorporeal Movement, an increase in Strength from 15 to 16, an increase in its attack bonus from +4 to +5, and an increase in hit points from 45 to 55.

entries.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The phantom wight can move through other creatures and objects as if they were {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

monsterFluff.name: Saber-Toothed Bat
entries: Despite its (relatively) small size, the saber-toothed bat fulfills the promise of its threatening name. The body of this bat is about the size of a small dog, but its 5-foot wingspan makes it look much larger. It's a vicious carnivore that hunts and kills just about anything, including other bats.

monsterFluff.name: Scar
entries: {@creature Scar|KPSC} is a {@creature tusked crimson ogre|CCodex} (Creature Codex). A healthy tusked crimson ogre's challenge rating is 5. Because of {@creature the Gaoler|KPSC}'s constant abuse, {@creature Scar|KPSC} has only 50 hit points, its Berserker's Blood ability does half damage (10 [{@damage 3d6}]), and a berserk creature repeats the saving throw at the end of its turn, ending the effect on itself on a success. These changes reduce {@creature Scar|KPSC} to challenge rating 3 (700 XP).

If you prefer, you can substitute a full-strength standard {@creature ogre} instead. Boost its AC to 14 and give it Blood Frenzy (the ogre has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points) and Multiattack (the ogre attacks once with its {@item greatclub|PHB} and once with a {@item javelin|PHB}). These changes increase the {@creature ogre} to challenge rating 3 (700 XP).

{@creature Solnis Ledniskol|KPSC} was a human woman who was captured by the deep ones decades ago and brought up the river along with her husband and three children; all were intended as sacrifices for the {@creature shoggoth|ToB}. Because the deep ones revel in cruelty, they reserved Solnis to be the final sacrifice. She was held captive for many days, during which she was tormented by the dying screams of her family.

When the deep ones came for her, Solnis broke loose and ran onto the bridge, where she wrapped her arms around a pursuing deep one and threw both of them into the river. As they fell she snatched a knife from the monster and stabbed it. The deep one died from the blade through its ribs and Solnis, trapped in the dying creature's grip, drowned in the watery gloom.

That small act of revenge barely scratched the surface of Solnis's thirst for vengeance. The superstitious deep ones fearfully left her corpse at the bottom of the river, where it transformed into a {@creature drowned maiden|ToB} (Tome of Beasts). Since her return to unlife, she's murdered dozens of deep ones. Now Solnis recalls her family only as vague shadows that urge her to kill, and she doesn't perceive much difference between the deep ones she hates and newcomers she doesn't know.
{@creature Solnis Ledniskol|KPSC} uses the standard {@creature drowned maiden|ToB} stat block with two changes.

items: When her Hair attack hits and grapples a creature, she can Reel that target as a bonus action on that turn.

She has the Rejuvenation trait: If the drowned maiden is destroyed, she regains all her hit points if the body is submerged in the Black River for 1 hour. She doesn't rejuvenate if the body is placed on dry land, if {@spell gentle repose} or comparable magic is cast on the body, or if a {@spell hallow} spell is cast on the portion of the Black River where she drowned.

monsterFluff.name: The Chained Thing
entries: {@creature The chained thing|KPSC} is an abominable undead creature patched together by Vardesain. It's the unholy melding of {@creature violet fungus|MM|violet fungi} and the corpses of at least two {@creature derro shadow antipaladin|ToB|derro shadow antipaladins}. Its existence is an unending nightmare of fear, pain, and longing for death.

The creature generates necrotic energy in a way that rejuvenates undead. That is its sole purpose, and the reason why Vardesain gifted one to {@creature Llagfel|KPSC} as a reward for her "conversion" to serving him and her transition to unlife as a {@creature hierophant lich|CCodex}.

{@creature The chained thing|KPSC} doesn't recognize friends or foes. Its thought process seldom wanders beyond "life is bad." It tries to snuff out anything with independent existence while instinctively, uncontrollably rejuvenating undeath.

Destroying {@creature the chained thing|KPSC} isn't easy because of its vast regenerative power. Radiant damage and the ghoul light are its only weaknesses. Thankfully, {@creature the chained thing|KPSC} is extraordinarily rare. Vardesain seldom allows more than one to exist at a time.

entries.name: Undead Rejuvenation
entries: {@creature The chained thing|KPSC} is a gift from Vardesain to a disciple who gained distinction through betrayal or some other service. That disciple and its followers can attune to {@creature the chained thing|KPSC} the same way a creature attunes to a magic item. When {@creature the chained thing|KPSC} unleashes its Necrotic Wave, all attuned, undead creatures at 0 hit points that are also within 100 feet of {@creature the chained thing|KPSC} recover all their hit points. This doesn't happen if {@creature the chained thing|KPSC}'s Regeneration is currently being prevented by radiant damage.

monsterFluff.name: The Gaoler
entries: {@creature The Gaoler|KPSC} is human, or he was at one time. He was a mercenary named Penkiletz who came to the Scarlet Citadel originally as {@creature Cagoth-ze|KPSC|Cagoth-ze's} bodyguard. Penkiletz foolishly took to bullying the alchemist {@creature Danaska Maksilov|KPSC} for sport. Eventually Maksilov had enough of the abuse and struck back with a unique concoction meant to turn her antagonist's sadistic impulses against anyone but the alchemist. The toxin succeeded at that but was more potent than expected: it seared Penkiletz's flesh and made him a target for his own cruelty along with everyone else. Any human decency he ever had was burned out of him by Maksilov's potion. Now known only as {@creature the Gaoler|KPSC}, he wants nothing but to torment the helpless and the innocent; when he can't get them, he torments himself.

monsterFluff.name: The Ghostly Foe
entries: Although it has many similarities to a ghost, {@creature the ghostly foe|KPSC} is not undead. It's an alien aberration from the Void that took up residence in the stones of Midgard.

A ghostly foe is a terrifying entity. It isn't a creature in the normal sense of that word; it's a consciousness that resides inside massive stones near powerful magical resonance, usually in the vicinity of a ley line or the terminus of a shadow road. When sentient creatures are nearby, the consciousness manifests as ghostly warriors that attack the intruders. The number of warriors can vary. Often it matches the number of intruders one-for-one, but not always. No matter how many manifestations there are, they all spring from the same consciousness. The manifestations are tough but can be destroyed with spells or mundane attacks. The only way known to destroy the underlying consciousness is with a {@spell wish}.
Although the ghostly manifestations in and of themselves aren't too dangerous, their attacks create openings in creatures' psyches for the ghostly presence to take control.

entries.name: Deadly Possession
entries: Possession by a ghostly foe is far more dangerous than possession by a {@creature ghost}, because {@creature the ghostly foe|KPSC} has access to the possessed creature's entire catalog of traits including knowledge, proficiencies, class abilities, and spells. Its weakness is that the alien presence of {@creature the ghostly foe|KPSC} in a creature's mind is anathema to flesh-and-blood creatures and eventually turns them to stone. {@creature The ghostly foe|KPSC} fights against it, but if the affected creature opens itself psychically to the effect, petrification is automatic. In this way, a powerful creature can opt to sacrifice itself instead of slaughtering its comrades.

A {@condition petrified} creature is restored to its normal state by {@spell greater restoration}, {@spell dispel evil and good}, or comparable magic. While {@condition petrified}, the creature must make a death saving throw every 10 days. A success or a natural 20 has no effect, but the creature dies after three failures.

monsterFluff.name: The Pale Circle
entries: {@creature Chansar the Pale|KPSC} and his five loyal retainers form the Pale Circle. All six are {@creature wight|MM|wights}. They use battleaxes instead of longswords. Four of them use standard wight statistics in every other regard. The other two have additional modifications to wight statistics.
{@creature Chansar the Pale|KPSC} has the trait Turning Defiance and wears a {@item ring of evasion}.

entries.name: Turning Defiance
entries: Chansar and any wights within 30 feet of him have advantage on saving throws against effects that turn undead.
One of the Pale Circle was a ring warden. Its Intelligence is 16, it has a Spellcasting ability, and it possesses a ring-staff that boosts its spell damage.

entries.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The ring warden wight is a 7th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). Spells marked with an asterisk are from Deep Magic by Kobold Press. These spells are also included elsewhere in the appendix under Deep Magic Spells.

entries.name: Bonded Ring-Staff (7/Day).
entries: When the ring warden wight rolls damage for a spell attack while holding its ring-staff, it adds +3 to the result. The ring warden wight can use the ring-staff as an {@item arcane focus|PHB}.

images.credit: One of: Miguel Regodn Harkness, Marcel Mercado, William O'Brien, Sam Perin, Florian Stitz, Bryan Syme, Egil Thompson, Jon Pintar

monsterFluff.name: Ushulx
entries: The blood cultist Ushulx uses the stat block of a standard {@creature cult fanatic} but with an altered spell list. Spells marked with an asterisk are from the Kobold Press book Deep Magic. They're repeated in the Deep Magic Spells section for convenience.

monsterFluff.name: Warlock Wight
entries: These are the rarest of all wights, since they're created only when warlocks who serve a particular, deceitful fiend fall completely for its lies and have themselves interred according to its complicated instructions. Most warlocks who serve fiends are smart enough to understand when they're being lied to by their patron, and even to expect it. Most, but not all.

No one knows the name or true nature of this fiend, since it never uses the same name or appearance twice when dealing with mortals. It's believed that for the fiend, that's part of the appeal in this arrangement.

Warlocks who become warlock wights are decapitated at the time of their interment. When the body rises, the head floats a few inches above the neck. Even when the body is destroyed, the head often survives and continues casting spells and draining life from its enemies.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A warlock wight doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Xymargshra is a spider of Leng (Tome of Beasts). It's no more or less cruel or avaricious than any other spider of Leng—which is to say, it's crueler and more avaricious than most humans can comprehend.
Xymargshra uses the standard spider of Leng stat block from Tome of Beasts, with two alterations.
First, it has Spider Climb.

entries.name: Spider Climb
entries: Xymargshra can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

Second, it has an expanded list of innate spells. Spells marked with an asterisk (*) are Void magic spells from Deep Magic. Their full descriptions are included under Deep Magic Spells in the appendix.

images.credit: One of: Miguel Regodn Harkness, Marcel Mercado, William O'Brien, Sam Perin, Florian Stitz, Bryan Syme, Egil Thompson, Jon Pintar

images.title: Concept Art from {@loader Warlock 20: Redtower|adventure/Kobold Press; Warlock 20 Redtower.json}
